editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Rector and Fellows of Exeter College.

msDesc.head: Robert Grosseteste, Dicta, sermones; etc.; Oxford?, England, s. xv1

msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.title: Dicta
msItem.incipit: itaque officium est tripartitum
msItem.explicit: [fol. 12v] vellet amor autem qui [nulli precepto]
msItem.incipit: [fol. 13r] et exclamacio eius
msItem.explicit: [fol. 24v] in lacum omnem preconsam [substanciam]
msItem.incipit: [fol. 25r] punt per accidens dici
msItem.explicit: [fol. 35v] reddit haustus aque cognicionis iusticie et misericordie.

msItem.title: [Tabula capitulorum]
msItem.incipit: 1. De amore et conceptu temporalium
msItem.explicit: 147. De aqua simpliciter et quibusdam aquis.
msItem.finalRubric: In hoc libello sunt capitula 147 ... quos eodem tempore ad clerum uel ad populum feci.

msItem.note: Thomson, Grosseteste, 24–32. Mostly unprinted but nos. 130 (fol. 25r), 141 (fols. 31v–2v) and 142 (fols. 32rv) are printed by E. Brown, Fasciculus rerum expetendarum et fugiendarum, 2 vols. (London, 1690), ii. 295–6, 288–90, 292–3, respectively. Because of the loss of leaves much text is lacking: fol. 1r begins in Dictum 51 and the loss of a quire after fol. 12, which ends in Dictum 72, causes a gap until (fol. 13r) Dictum 93; fol. 24v ends in Dictum 107, and resumes (fol. 25r) in Dictum 123. On Grosseteste see Sharpe, Latin Writers.

msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste (?)
msItem.incipit: aptatur nam alum pro anima ponitur
msItem.explicit: et contemplaciorum affecioni [in bono]
msItem.note: Unidentified; probably Grosseteste. Continuing from a missing page, it begins immediately after item 1 in a different hand, and was continued on a page which is now also lacking.

msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.title: Sermons
msItem.note: For Grosseteste’s sermons references are to Thomson, Grosseteste, 164, and Schneyer, 5. 177 et seq.

msItem.incipit: quia ad thesaurorum
msItem.explicit: cum Deo patre reconciliantis.

msItem.incipit: Beatus Paulus apostolus discipulum
msItem.explicit: optimo usu et ordinatissimo fine composuerunt exterius.

msItem.incipit: Erunt signa in sole et luna et stellis requirentibus discipulis a domino
msItem.explicit: cum ipso fulgeamus sicut sol in regno patris sui sine fine Amen.

msItem.incipit: Pauper et inops laudabunt nomen tuum. Canitur hodie in laude bead Martini. Martinus hic pauper et modicus ... consuevimus autem vocare pauperes
msItem.explicit: et in futuro premiorum honore fulgebis.

msItem.incipit: Conuenitis ex consuetudine ad collationem quasi ad alicuius admirabilis
msItem.explicit: breuis sit hoc nobis huius collatiunculi finis.

msItem.incipit: Exiit edictum a Cesare Augusto verus princeps mundi terrenis mundi principibus
msItem.explicit: coronauit predictorum circulorum diademate.

msItem.incipit: Beati pauperes spiritu. vos omnes et singuli
msItem.explicit: et subiecta figura visibiliter descripcimus.

msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.title: Sermons

msItem.incipit: Dominus noster Ihesus eternus eterni patris filius
msItem.explicit: a me peccatore extremo est attemptatum.
msItem.note: Grosseteste, Sermo 14 (Thomson), Sermo 16 (Schneyer, v. 178), i.e. Memorandum to pope Innocent IV and the curia, 13 May, 1250. Ed. S. Gieben, ‘Robert Grosseteste at the Papal Curia, Lyons 1250: edition of the documents’, Collectanea Franciscana, 41 (1971), 340–93. See also Thomson, Grosseteste, 141–7.

Items 4(ii–vii) following are parts of the dossier relating to the occasion of Grosseteste’s visit to the curia and his denunciation of ecclesiastical customs. Our collection lacks the Parabola (Gieben, 370–2). The text of our manuscript (his E) is described by Gieben as being ‘sorely astray'. There are countless omissions which indicate that the scribe must have been pressed for time and consequendy decided to stick to the essentials. Often he does not care about the ending of a word or about its correct spelling … Noteworthy are his errors by metathesis, which sometimes creates odd variants like strangulari/transgulari. Nevertheless, some correct readings and even a few larger omissions are preserved only in this manuscript.’

msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.title: Conquestio cleri anglie
msItem.incipit: Itaque post primo proponita paucis diebus elapsis
msItem.explicit: inconsuetas procuraciones.

msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.title: De regno et tyrannide
msItem.incipit: Tercio si verba philosophica possent ... De regno et rege et tirannide
msItem.explicit: iuuante domino sufficienter ostenditur

msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.title: De iure eiusque apparatibus
msItem.incipit: Quarto quia ad hec quidam cardinalium
msItem.explicit: pre omnibus tenemini.

msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.title: De lege et justo
msItem.incipit: Tandem idem episcopus sicut domino
msItem.explicit: et ad infernalia deificatis.

msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.title: Defensio sui
msItem.incipit: Interim dum predicta agerentur
msItem.explicit: eminencia sunt angelus et deus ... scripsit in hunc modum.

msItem.author: Robert Marsh, archdeacon of Oxford
msItem.title: Introduction to Grosseteste’s Memorandum
msItem.incipit: Anno domini .mº. ccº. iº feria viª post ascencionem domini ... [fol. 67r] ... Ecce quam bonum et quam jocundum habitari fratres
msItem.explicit: in domo eius omnibus diebus vite vestre.
msItem.note: ed. Gieben, 350. On Marsh see Sharpe, Latin Writers.

msItem.title: Sermon
msItem.incipit: Erit firmamentum in terra. Christus est firmamentum primum quia ipse est primogenitus
msItem.explicit: Per memoriam tangit firmamentum ... per meditacionem aut diligentem non agnitorum inuestigacioni.

msItem.incipit: Canimus in laudem beate virginis. Tota pulcra es amica mea et macula
msItem.explicit: in quo creaturis omnibus restituit antequam dignitatem.

msItem.incipit: Prelati et doctores ecclesie et apostoli oculi sunt. Congruit enim illis
msItem.explicit: ad fine creaturarum fonte velut axis processionem.

msItem.incipit: Christus in scriptura frequenter sol nominatur ut in Malach’
msItem.explicit: patent contrariorum verborum non distincciones sentencia.
msItem.note: Grosseteste, Sermo 25 (Thomson), Sermo 27 (Schneyer, v. 178, but with a different ending).

msItem.incipit: Qui autem sunt Christi ... Caro potest intelligi ipsa carnis
msItem.explicit: bonorum suauitate fortiter attrahente.

msItem.incipit: Ad uerificacionem sequencium proprietatum que in superioribus non moralizantur
msItem.explicit: unde tu possis proficere et perfectus est etc.

msItem.incipit: Tribulatur homo cum amittit inuitus
msItem.explicit: saluacio et tandem beatitudo.

msItem.incipit: Absinthium tali dum [recte calidum] est et siccum coroboracionem stomachi
msItem.explicit: penam diluas et culpam etc.

msItem.title: Sermon
msItem.incipit: Si rex est qui recte regit populum suum
msItem.explicit: auctoritates patenter quedam spiritus quedam ad litteram assumpt’.

msItem.title: Sermon
msItem.incipit: Timor est apprehensio inconuenientis in opinione quod erit. Est eciam timor fuga
msItem.explicit: ne pereas tunc ne displicias.

msItem.incipit: Ecclesia sancta celebrat hodie solemnitatem resurreccionis
msItem.explicit: pro nobis resurrexit Rex gloriosus Amen.

msItem.incipit: Premonitus a uenerabili Patre Otone
msItem.explicit: euidenter sapiencia set et [archangelos]
msItem.note: Grosseteste, Sermo 19 (Thomson), Sermo 21 (Schneyer, v. 178). Our text ends abruptly because of the loss of the next quire.

msItem.incipit: finit dulcia in cuius fortitudinem
msItem.explicit: filii dei secundum diuinitatem
msItem.note: A fragment of an unidentified sermon, beginning abruptly because of the loss of the preceding quire and ending abruptly because of the loss of the second leaf of quire 10. The text is probably Grosseteste or Ps.-Grosseteste.

msItem.author: Ps.-Grosseteste
msItem.title: Sermo de septem gradibus contemplativorum
msItem.incipit: mulcet suam pinguedinem
msItem.explicit: quem lacte virgineo educant manibus contractauit scilicet dominum nostrum Ihesum Christum benedictum in secula seculorum Amen.
msItem.note: pr. Bonaventura, Opera, vii (Rome, 1596), 104–5, our text beginning at 104b/9. ‘Sermo 37’, Thomson, 177; also Spurium 24, ibid. 250–1, q.v. for the various attributions.

msItem.author: Robert Grosseteste
msItem.title: De decem mandatis
msItem.incipit: Sequitur de mandatis domini. Sicut dicit apostolus plenitudo legis est dileccio
msItem.explicit: vt ipsis fruatur summo [opere]
msItem.note: ed. R. C. Dales and E. B. King, Auctores Britannici Medii Aevi, 10 (1987) (MS ‘Ex’), who comment that chapters 3–4 and many quotations are omitted. Our text ends in IX. 10, edn. 89/19; Thomson, Grosseteste, 131–2.
[At top, ‘Iste liber valet xxs. emi pro xvjs. xd. posterius feci scribi sermones in eo et sic valet xxxvs.’ Below this, in another hand of s. xv, is a contents list.]

The original part of the volume is presumably item 1. The contents list follows the order of much of this volume but with curious extras. It lists our sermons 2, 3(iii–vii), 4(ii–vii), 6(i), 6(iii)?, 7, 9(i–ii) but also includes six sermons between our sermons 2 and 3(iii) which can never have been in this volume, at least at that point, since the existing text is continuous: they are Schneyer nos. 5, 6, 11, 12 = Thomson nos. 4, 5, 9, 10. It further includes ‘Sermo in colla. siue ordinacione’ and ‘alius de episcopis’; one of which might be our 3(ii). The verso is blank and was once pasted down.

supportDesc.extent:
107 leaves preceded by two 18th-century paper flyleaves and followed by one medieval membrane flyleaf and two 18th-century paper flyleaves. 328 240
230–35 80
supportDesc.foliation: Now foliated in pencil but before Coxe’s time paginated.
supportDesc.collation: 1–312 4–98 108 (wants 2) 118 128 (wants 5) 132 (wants 1). There are catchwords, not in the scribes’ hands, and red quire signatures in the form of small letters and roman figures on items 3–11.

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns, c. 50–53 lines. Ruled in crayon.

handDesc.handNote: Fols. 1r–12v, text hand; some punctuation added in 15th century. Fols. 13–36vb/27, text hand; occasional punctuation by virgula. Fols. 36va/28 to end of page, bastard anglicana, with occasional punctuation by double virgula; fols. 37r–107v, anglicana, unpunctuated. For a comment on the standard achieved by the scribe of fols. 13r–107v see note to item 4(i) 1 above.

decoDesc.decoNote: 3/4-line blue lombards flourished red at beginning of each item. Red and blue paraphs. In the sermons the lombards do not always succeed in guiding the reader through the text of item 4, since the scribe left spaces for them at the wrong places.

binding.p: Sewn on four bands. Standard Exeter binding: simple and quite elegant, calf over millboards, the calf bearing blind decoration of a floral type, early 19th century.

history.provenance: After having the additional material added to its nucleus (see item *13) the book came to Exeter in 1418 as part of the estate of M. Thomas Plymiswode, donor of MSS 23 and 43 (Rector’s Accounts, winter 1418; Boase1, 10–11, Boase2, 22).
Probably Ecloga, no. 24, CMA, no. 33, (‘Grosthed … Tractatus de Mandatis—De cura Pastorali’).
On fol. iv are two notes in 19th-century hands on the loss of leaves from the book.

Exeter library identifications are: on the front pastedown, bookplate 3, and on it ‘Q8—1 Gall’, deleted and replaced by ‘172–G–1’, and ‘Coxe xxi’ on it; and on fol. iv Coxe Cat. no. xvi’. ‘1’ is on a round paper label at the top of the spine.

source.bibl: Andrew G. Watson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Exeter College, Oxford (Oxford: Oxford University Press), 2000.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Exeter College Library.
